claims.claim: Intratumoral mRNA vaccination triggers local innate sensing and type I interferon signaling within the tumor microenvironment.

evidence.quote: Type I interferon response score (normalized units) | 3.1
Blocking type I interferon signaling with anti-IFNAR1 eliminated the observed sensitization benefit.

claims.caveat: The mechanistic readouts were strongest in specific model systems rather than uniformly across all tested settings.

claims.claim: Interferon-associated antigen processing and presentation pathways increase after mRNA vaccination, leading to a broader peptide repertoire on MHC-I molecules.

evidence.quote: Fraction of proteins represented in MHC-I peptidome | 40.6% | 20.6%
Interferon-associated antigen processing and presentation pathways increase.

claims.caveat: The expansion of MHC-I-presented peptides was primarily demonstrated in mouse models; human translational evidence is indirect.

claims.claim: PD-L1 pathway activity increases after mRNA vaccination, creating a rationale for combining with immune checkpoint blockade.

evidence.quote: PD-L1 expression fold-change in tumor tissue | 2.4x

claims.caveat: While PD-L1 expression increased, the direct clinical benefit in combination therapy requires prospective validation.

claims.claim: The combination of intratumoral mRNA vaccination with anti-PD-L1 therapy improves tumor control in preclinical mouse models.

evidence.quote: Combined intervention improves tumor control in mice
Mouse efficacy cohort (combination therapy): 78 tumor-bearing mice pooled across repeat experiments.

claims.caveat: Mouse model effects may not map one-to-one to all human tumors due to species differences in immune responses.

claims.claim: Prior SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination is associated with improved survival outcomes in metastatic cancer patients receiving immune checkpoint inhibitors.

evidence.quote: Retrospective human survival comparison p-value | p=0.01
Vaccinated subgroup had improved survival under ICI treatment

claims.caveat: The human analysis is retrospective and non-randomized; vaccination timing varied across patients and confounding factors likely exist.

claims.claim: Lipid nanoparticle delivery vehicles lacking mRNA do not reproduce the tumor sensitization effects observed with mRNA-containing vaccines.

evidence.quote: Lipid particle controls lacking mRNA did not reproduce the sensitization effect.

claims.caveat: The control experiments confirmed that mRNA content, rather than just the delivery vehicle, is responsible for the observed biological effects.
